Subjective: Irritated right eye since Tuesday morning; feels like hair or speck of dust in eye; redness and swelling; no pain unless squeezing eyes shut; no impact on vision; no fever, cough, or shortness of breath; no recent travel or exposure to chemicals; no smoking/alcohol; Request: Wants to know if it's an eye infection and if antibiotics are needed; Concern: Worried about contagiousness and impact on daughter Isa.
Objective: Vitals: not recorded; Physical Exam: Right eye: redness, swelling, and increased tear production; Left eye: mild redness; Pupils: reactive to light; No discharge or pus; No tenderness to palpation.
Assessment: Viral conjunctivitis; No signs of bacterial infection or other conditions.
Plan: • Explanation: Viral conjunctivitis is self-limiting and will resolve on its own; • Medication: Artificial tears for symptomatic relief; • Advice: Avoid rubbing eyes and try to keep them clean; • Safety netting: Return to clinic if symptoms worsen, or if pain, pus, or vision changes occur; • Follow-up: Schedule follow-up appointment in 2 weeks if symptoms persist.
